items.title: Swiss interior minister open to social media ban for children
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: Switzerland’s Interior Minister Elisabeth Baume-Schneider signaled openness to restricting social media for minors, saying she would study measures inspired by Australia’s under-16 ban and EU debates. A report will guide next steps, with options including a full ban on social platforms for children, limits on harmful content, and curbing algorithmic targeting of youth; platforms could also be held responsible for what children consume. The discussion follows a separate move by the canton of Fribourg to bar mobile phones for students until around age 15 to reduce youth device use.

items.title: China issues new rules to regulate internet platform pricing
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- CAC issues pricing rules for internet platforms, effective April 10, banning coercive price pressure via higher fees or search ranking bans.
- Measures target unfavourable practices even as big platforms press on with an instant-retail price war.
- Consumers may enjoy lower prices, but merchants face tighter margins and restaurateurs report weaker in-person business.

items.title: Meta's Dina Powell McCormick quits board, may stay on as adviser
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Dina Powell McCormick resigned from Meta's board effective immediately after eight months.
- She may continue advising Meta in a broad investments and strategic-counsel role; Meta won't fill her vacant seat.
- The board, which recently expanded to 15 members, retains figures such as Marc Andreessen and Tony Xu.

items.title: EU Council backs digital euro with both online and offline functionality
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- EU Council backs a negotiating position for a digital euro issued by the ECB, usable online and offline, diverging from Parliament’s offline-only stance.
- Online payments use the central bank ledger or intermediaries; offline payments are recorded locally then synced, preserving cash-like privacy and ECB-set holding caps.
- A minimum five-year transition would cap interchange/merchant fees; after adoption the ECB could issue the euro, with a 2027 pilot and potential 2029 rollout amid banking-sector resistance.

items.title: Strategy and bitcoin-buying firms face wider exclusion from stock indexes
items.author: Elizabeth Howcroft
items.summary: • MSCI will decide by Jan 15 whether to exclude digital asset treasury (DAT) firms if crypto holdings reach 50%+ of assets, potentially reshaping demand for bitcoin-treasury stocks. • Exclusion could trigger large outflows from passive funds; for MicroStrategy, estimates range from about $2.8B to as much as ~$9B across multiple indexes. • Crypto firms dispute the rule; Nasdaq monitoring response; spillovers could affect a roughly $15T passive universe.
